{{post-nominals|KCMG}} (13 January 1914 – 30 September 1981), was the 6th 'C' (i.e., Director) of the [[Secret Intelligence Service]] (MI6) from 1968 to 1973. ==Career== Educated at [[Wellington College (Berkshire)|Wellington College]] and [[Balliol College, Oxford]], Rennie joined an advertising agency in [[New York]] in 1935.<ref name=odnb>[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/31597?docPos=3 John Rennie at Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]</ref> During [[World War II]] he worked at an organisation in [[Baltimore]] combating [[Germany|German]] propaganda.<ref name=odnb/> In 1946 he joined the [[Foreign Office]] and was posted to [[Washington D.C.]] and then to [[Warsaw]].<ref name=odnb/> In 1953 he was appointed Head of the [[Information Research Department]], a controversial body established to disseminate information about the dangers of [[Soviet Union|Soviet]]-style [[communism]].<ref name=odnb/> During the [[Suez Crisis]] he chaired a committee established to disseminate British propaganda in the [[Middle East]].<ref name=odnb/> He was posted to [[Buenos Aires]] in 1958 and [[Washington D.C.]] in 1960.<ref name=odnb/> He served on the [[Civil Service Commission]] in 1966.<ref name=odnb/> Then in 1968 he was appointed Chief of the Secret Intelligence Service.<ref name=odnb/> On 15 January 1973, Rennie's son Charles and his daughter-in-law were arrested for an alleged involvement in the importation of large quantities of [[heroin]] from [[Hong Kong]].<ref name=odnb/> Rennie resigned not long afterwards.<ref name=odnb/> Another son is the [[The Economist]] columnist [[David Rennie (columnist)|David Rennie]].
